message.content:
While the 5MHz frequency may provide a shorter range than other frequencies, it offers faster communication speeds and can support more simultaneous users. But the actual range of this frequency depends on several factors like signal strength and quality, network infrastructure, environmental conditions (such as vegetation or buildings), weather conditions, receiver type (including sensitivity) and even human interference.

In an unobstructed outdoor environment with good reception on both ends, ideal line-of-sight conditions would cover a distance of around 3-10 km (~1.86-6.2 miles). However, in urban settings with many buildings and obstacles to navigate through such as walls or trees between sender/receiver antennas could experience weaker signals that limit distance to only hundreds of meters; up to a mile or two at best based on location circumstances present.

Antenna gain also plays significant role dictating how farthest reach spectrum go â€“ higher levels mean wider coverage areas so investing well-made device increases likelihood achieving further connections reaching out over much greater lengths than ordinary hardware might allow alone
